item.title: Tensions Surge in Venezuela After Vote
item.description: Political tension in Venezuela rose after the government said it would proclaim acting President Nicolás Maduro as president-elect later in the day, despite opposition calls for a full recount from the bitterly contested election.

item.title: Japan Readies 'Third Arrow'
item.description: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe launched the third part of his strategy to revive Japan's growth—a government push to better use the Internet and digital technology to overhaul the country's regimented economy.

item.title: Railway Spending Up in China
item.description: China spent $8.8 billion on railway infrastructure construction in the first quarter, up 28% from a year earlier.

item.title: EU Rejects Carbon-Permit Plan
item.description: Lawmakers' rejection of a proposal which would result in carbon dioxide emissions becoming more expensive calls into question the future of Europe's environmental goals.

item.title: Hopes Dim for Inter-Korean Reset
item.description: As North Korea issues fresh war threats, South Korean President Park Geun-hye's hopes of improving relations with Pyongyang by building trust look increasingly bleak.

item.title: U.K. Reviews Security for Thatcher Funeral
item.description: British authorities said they are reviewing their security arrangements for Wednesday's funeral of former Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and Sunday's London Marathon following Monday's explosions at the Boston Marathon.

item.title: Dozens Die in Iraq Attacks
item.description: More than 25 bombings across Iraq left at least 61 people dead on Monday, adding uncertainty and instability ahead of the first elections since U.S. troops left the country in December 2011.

item.title: Somalia Seeks Help to Fight Militants
item.description: Somalia's fledging democratic government appealed for its people to help fight a militant group it said carried out a gun and bomb assault on the nation's highest court the day before.

item.title: Seoul Announces Extra Budget
item.description: South Korea on Tuesday announced a $15.44 billion extra government budget to spur growth in Asia's fourth-largest economy, in the first such fiscal stimulus in four years.

item.title: Asian Counterfeit Trade Grows
item.description: Counterfeit goods, mainly from China, have become as profitable for Asia's criminal gangs as illegal drug trafficking, a U.N. report says.

item.title: Weather Scrutinized in Lion Air Crash
item.description: Extreme weather conditions are being looked at as one of the possible causes of the crash of a Lion Air jet off the island of Bali.

item.title: Kerry Focuses on Iran, N. Korea Leaders
item.description: U.S. Secretary of State Kerry, in his push to stabilize North Asia and the Middle East, is wrestling to understand the strategic calculations of two obscure and autocratic men.

item.title: Turkish Pianist Gets Suspended Term
item.description: World-renowned Turkish concert pianist Fazil Say was handed a suspended jail sentence in Istanbul for insulting Islam on Twitter in a controversial court decision that supporters say protects Islamic values but critics maintain curbs free speech.

item.title: Greece on Track for Aid Tranche
item.description: Greece and international inspectors wrapped up talks on the steps the country must take to secure its next disbursement of aid—and which include laying off some 15,000 public sector workers—following weeks of negotiations.

item.title: In Privacy-Loving France, Ministers Disclose Assets
item.description: The French premier and his 37 ministers disclosed their assets—an unusual exercise in a country where the political class has long resisted measures to increase transparency.

item.title: Anticorruption Group Seeks Probe of Angolan Deal
item.description: An anticorruption group is asking Swiss prosecutors to reopen an investigation of bankers and officials connected to Angola's President José Eduardo dos Santos, based on what it describes as new evidence that alleges the president collected tens of millions of dollars in kickbacks in the 1990s.

item.title: Slower China Growth Signals Days of Miracles Are Waning
item.description: After three decades of annual economic growth in China averaging around 10%, many industries are now experiencing less bling and more blah.

item.title: Greeks See Ray of Hope in Tourist Bookings
item.description: Greece's tourism industry is counting on a million more visitors this year, something that would provide a welcome boost to the economy.

item.title: Merkel Rivals Struggle to Find Foothold
item.description: Angela Merkel's opponents have been trying to knock her from power in September's election. With the vote five months away, the opposition is in a quandary.

item.title: A Trudeau Follows in Pierre's Dance Steps
item.description: Justin Trudeau, the 41-year-old son of legendary Canadian Prime Minister Pierre Trudeau has captured attention in a flashy campaign to win leadership of the opposition Liberal party.

item.title: Photos of the Day: April 15
item.description: In today's pictures, baseball players remember Jackie Robinson in Boston, North Korea marks an anniversary, a man goes face-to-face with a sculpture in Paris, and more.

item.title: Pulitzer-Winning Breaking-News Photography
item.description: A set of photos by Rodrigo Abd, Manu Brabo, Narciso Contreras, Khalil Hamra and Muhammed Muheisen, all of the Associated Press, won the Pulitzer Prize for breaking-news photography.

item.title: Lamborghinis and Camels, on Patrol
item.description: Police officers in the emirate of Dubai recently began patrolling in a Lamborghini Aventador. But they aren't the first police officers to hop a cool ride.
